channel.description: Recent content in forensics on Analyst

item.title: GCFA
item.description: This is my GCFA study plan. I hope it will help me in organizing and prioritising the topics to learn and also in estimating the time I need to get ready.

item.description: This is my GCFA study plan. I hope it will help me in organizing and prioritising the topics to learn and also in estimating the time I need to get ready.

item.title: Chromesque Internals
item.description: In the process of investigating Toy PD case, I‚Äôve realised I lack the information about different browser files.

item.title: Evidence Collection And Preservation Methodology
item.description: For each OS and system type there will be a separate section (see below). However, the main principles will remain the same.

item.title: Log Analysis Methodology
item.description: One of the most useful artifacts when properly configured and maintained, are log files. All devices keep some sort of logs, even mobile devices.

item.title: Process Injections
item.description: Windows Most of the information is taken from here, but more visualization is added. The screenshots from IDA Pro are also copied from that blog post.

item.title: ‚õîÔ∏è Access Controls
item.description: DAC I am the leader! I’m the one that says when we go. A user, who’s the owner of the file or another object defines who can and who cannot view it.

item.title: üí´ System Supernova
item.description: One of the main things to know when performing forensic analysis is knowing what’s normal and what’s not. It would take ages to google every single pinch of this information, that’s why I have decided to make a clean install of several systems and capture their state to have an idea what’s good for each of them.

item.title: üóí Account Information Methodology
item.description: Windows There are two main places within the registry that contains that information: SAM hive for local and Microsoft accounts and Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\ProfileList for Domain Accounts.

item.title: üóí Methodology
item.description: First, have a template for an IR/forensics sheet. This can be done in Excel or other program alike.

item.title: Apple Partition Map
item.description: APFS is not very much described from the forensic perspective. I wonder how much APM is described.

item.title: GUID Partition Table
item.description: GUID is an identifier of the following format: 8-4-4-4-12. There is still a protective MBR at 0 so that Windows will not try to format the disk.

item.title: Master Boot Record
item.description: Stands for Master Boot Record. Primary partitions (bootable). Can have at most 4 bootable partitions, since it’s limited to 4 partition entries in parition table, each entry 16 bytes in length.

item.title: üß∞ Data Recovery Techniques
item.description: Below are the techniques, tools and instructions regarding data recovery from various file systems and devices. Most of the below techniques apply to HDDs only. Those that are for SDDs or other flash memory devices will be specified in the last section.

item.title: Logs Collection
item.description: macOS syslog. Since macOS Sierra (10.12, 2016) Apple has redesigned its log system. Unix logs were replaced (syslog, for example).

item.description: Are there any Shadow Cloud Accounts? Could be the first place to look when investigating.

item.title: üßº Media Sterilisation
item.description: Before copying evidence or making a disk image one needs to sterelise the target media to make sure that data that was present on that disk prior to this operation would not meddle with the evidence data.

item.title: ü™ü Windows Evidence Collection
item.description: Stacking - outlier analysis based on frequency. File Systems FAT12, 32, 64, NTFS, ReFS. Logical Backup - doesn’t copy all, doesn’t copy slack, free space and deleted files.

item.title: AWS Logs
item.description: This document is devoted to AWS logs. Several examples are analysed and useful fields are marked.

item.title: FSEvents
item.description: Intro Directory events only 10.5-10.6. File events since 10.7. Each record is assigned a name which is constucted the following way: hex(last_event_id + 1).

item.title: Git
item.description: Git is a version control tool. I am putting it in this section since it’s basically logging all that happens within the repo.

item.title: üìö Wireless
item.description: Attacks iwconfig airmon-ng check kill airmon-ng start wlan0 iwconfig airodump-ng wlan0mon airdump-ng -c <channel number> --bssid <access point MAC> -w capture wlan0mon to capture the handshake or enough data to deduce the key.

item.title: üñ• System Information
item.description: Windows Installed programs and applications Key üîë: Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall. There can be some data for programs that do not exist on the system anymore.

item.title: Data Exfiltration
item.description: These are my ideas on IR playbooks for training. Don’t judge :) We don’t evolve if we don’t make mistakes and learn from them. And we don’t make mistakes if we do nothing. Even if I am risking to become an object of ridicule, I am posting this article. I am planning to imporve once I learn more or gain some relevant experience.

item.title: MacOS Core Processes
item.description: There are two broad categories of core processes. Processes that initialize system environment and those that initialize the user environment. Whatever is the category, you need to know them well in order to detect abnormal things.

item.title: Browser Info
item.description: Many browsers are based on Chromium engine, that‚Äôs why they will have similar artifacts: Chrome, Opera, new Edge, Brave, Vivaldi.

item.title: C&C Patterns
item.description: Network You will need pcap files for that: https://www.activecountermeasures.com/free-tools/rita/. Forward: attacker connects to the victim. Reverse: victim connects to the attacker (harder to detect).

item.title: Console Activity Analysis Methodology
item.description: Remote vs local commands? Windows CMD PowerShell Windows PowerShell Event logs Operational Monitoring. %SystemRoot%\System32\winevt\Logs\Microsoft-Windows-Powershell%Operational.evtx, ID 4103, 4104 (if Windows considers suspicious).

item.title: MacOS Terminal Logs
item.description: By default, all console data is not being logged. Only staff that was typed with sudo is.

item.title: UNIX Console
item.description: Bash On most Linux machines bash is the default shell interpereter. Each user has a separate bash history.

item.description: Collection Most of the devices keep some sort of logs. As for the network related issues these are switches, routers, firewalls, IDS and IPS, web proxies, DC and authentication servers, DCHP server and application servers.

item.title: Media Files
item.description: Windows Recent documents Key üîë: NTUSER.DAT\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\RecentDocs Contains the list of all recent documents as a bunch and also the same data sorted by extension.

item.title: ‚õÖÔ∏è Cloud Storage
item.description: Windows For OneDrive the most useful artifacts are stored locally. If you get access to the account online - may see the deleted items and their versions.

item.title: üìÑ Document And Folder Artefacts
item.description: There are several ways to determine file type: extension, signatures and structure. The most reliable is the last one, since extentsions can be easily changed and signatures are not very reliable (polymorphic files).

item.title: Incident Response & Hunting Across the Enterprise | Advanced Adversary & Anti-Forensics Detection
item.description: Legend Below is the skeleton from SAN508 course description. I am using it to make up my study plan.

item.title: üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Recent Activity Methodology
item.description: Basically, all of the artefacts that are listed in the Investigation section fall under the category “user activity” one way or another. Even if some process spawned some other process, somewhere in the past the user interaction was still required. That’s why I find it so hard to find the perfect categorization. I’ve decided to devote this section to common strategies of how one would investigate user activity and which artefacts they would use at what point in time.

item.title: üí¨‚ùóÔ∏èNotifications
item.description: Windows Toast notifications on Windows 10: C:\Users\%Username%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\Notifications contains wpndatabase.db and appdb.dat. Both can be opened with üõ† SQLite Browser.

item.title: üó£ Voice Assistants
item.description: Windows Cortana is a great source of information. C:\Users\%Username%\AppData\Local\Packages\Microsoft.Windows.Cortana_xxxx\LocalState\ESEDatabase_CortanaCoreInstance\CortanaCoreDb.db contains user locations, reminders etc. Use a üõ† SQLite browser to see the contents, or export to cvs and work in Excel.

item.description: COM (Component Object Model) objects are a way to let processes call other processes. A process, that needs to call someone else loads a COM.dll into it’s address space.

item.title: Sample Questions
item.description: List of tools List of reg entries List of known malware and ioc Terminology List of artefacts (Win and Lin) List of attacks List of scans and their footprint (try map against different OS and log the results) Re-read those diaries, might be of help Configure laboratory (Wins I have + WinXP + Linux Hacking + Linux Kali) Install WinServer VM with AD and learn the basics (Udemy course may be + Hahacking + questions) ‚ùì Which of the following encryption methods use the RC4 technology?
